It is 2113.
Cities have undergone profound change by around 2050.
Urban population had grown exponentially and resources were more scarce than ever before.
Human obsession with owning resources led to the fragmentation and collapse of society.
The first wave of hope came in the form of collaborative consumption.
This had begun decades before, but only minorities had engaged.
Citizens started to share their resources to make sure that everybody would have access to shelter, food and transport.
Sharing became public policy when ownership became an old luxury.
The first years of the sharing economy were fantastic.
People would meet face to face and agree on how and when to share what they had.

These repeated interactions between city and strangers fostered trust and social capital, but desire for more efficiency and increasing the number of transactions led to the development of highly sophisticated sharing systems that precluded social interaction.
Computerized systems would manage the resources, allocating them according to data customization and convenience.
You could be picked up from the airport by a shared electric car and driven to someone else is flat.
Without ever seeing that person.
Sharing schemes of old rapidly.
We started by sharing resources and data from pictures to videos, personal information, and quantified self data.

But gradually equipped with all sorts of sensors capable of recording information from electroencephalogram to visual stimuli, smells and somatic experiences, we began to share the most sensible data about our human experience.
Too busy to visit my parents for Christmas.
I would remotely send the smell of my dinner to my mother and she would answer with the somatic experience of my father's hug.
But time passed by and we were sad again.
The streets were empty in public places, abandoned people lost agency with the physical world and with others.
I remember spending three days at a strangers home in Upper Street and struggling to understand where I was, what day it was or how it got in there.
I played and played in an endless loop, my father's hug, but something became uncanny about that feeling a sense of social isolation eroded our happiness.
And we start to develop all sorts of schizophrenic behavior.
Large amounts of public funding was given to researchers working on new interactive systems to foster social connectedness again.
We needed it.
Now it is 2113 and this is our second wave of hope.
Wearing on new technologies, we have achieved ultimate connectivity.
We enjoy augmented experiences as long as we sync our senses with others in proximity, you can see what I see, but only as long as we look in each others eyes.
You can feel like I feel or like I felt yesterday, but only if we actually touch.
We can share the intimacy of our dearest memories, but that requires a deeper connection and the release of specific neuromodulators such as oxytocin.
In a society that relies on data sharing for most of its processes, and you exchange system based on reputation, is required.
We now have aura points.
A new currency based on how well you are dealing with others and our shared resource is your aura points.
Determine your aggregated reputation and whether others can trust you for sharing or not in an aura economy.
Finally, what you give is what you get.

It is 2113.
Cities have undergone profound change by around 2050.
Urban population had grown exponentially and resources were more scarce than ever before.
Human obsession with owning resources led to the fragmentation and collapse of society.
The first wave of hope came in the form of collaborative consumption.
This had begun decades before, but only minorities had engaged.
Citizens started to share their resources to make sure that everybody would have access to shelter, food and transport.
Sharing became public policy when ownership became an old luxury.
The first years of the sharing economy were fantastic.
People would meet face to face and agree on how and when to share what they had.

These repeated interactions between city and strangers fostered trust and social capital, but desire for more efficiency and increasing the number of transactions led to the development of highly sophisticated sharing systems that precluded social interaction.
Computerized systems would manage the resources, allocating them according to data customization and convenience.
You could be picked up from the airport by a shared electric car and driven to someone else is flat.
Without ever seeing that person.
Sharing schemes of old rapidly.
We started by sharing resources and data from pictures to videos, personal information, and quantified self data.

But gradually equipped with all sorts of sensors capable of recording information from electroencephalogram to visual stimuli, smells and somatic experiences, we began to share the most sensible data about our human experience.
Too busy to visit my parents for Christmas.
I would remotely send the smell of my dinner to my mother and she would answer with the somatic experience of my father's hug.
But time passed by and we were sad again.
The streets were empty in public places, abandoned people lost agency with the physical world and with others.
I remember spending three days at a strangers home in Upper Street and struggling to understand where I was, what day it was or how it got in there.
I played and played in an endless loop, my father's hug, but something became uncanny about that feeling a sense of social isolation eroded our happiness.
And we start to develop all sorts of schizophrenic behavior.
Large amounts of public funding was given to researchers working on new interactive systems to foster social connectedness again.
We needed it.
Now it is 2113 and this is our second wave of hope.
Wearing on new technologies, we have achieved ultimate connectivity.
We enjoy augmented experiences as long as we sync our senses with others in proximity, you can see what I see, but only as long as we look in each others eyes.
You can feel like I feel or like I felt yesterday, but only if we actually touch.
We can share the intimacy of our dearest memories, but that requires a deeper connection and the release of specific neuromodulators such as oxytocin.
In a society that relies on data sharing for most of its processes, and you exchange system based on reputation, is required.
